p: Significant human health impacts of a changing climate have been experienced across the globe. For example, the European heat wave of 2003 resulted in 30,000 to 50,000 premature deaths [11]. On-going prolonged droughts in several parts of the world including South Asia, Australia, and North-Eastern and West Africa have resulted in severe damage to infrastructure and settlements, extensive crop failures, premature deaths and migration of many refugees [2], [11]. Human health-related impacts tend to be more severe in impoverished countries due to poor economies, socioeconomic structures, and currently fewer resources to adapt and respond to climatic changes. In developed countries such as Canada, researchers, health practitioners and decision-makers are making strides in working together to share knowledge and resources to build capacity within health systems and communities to address health concerns.
